you guys should have touched on the fact that MILLIONS of humans cannot visualize in their heads. its not something you can learn, you are born with it or you aren't.
Â @FeedMeSaltÂ  Visualizing is a skill not an ability. Go watch movies or read books(books work especially well).

Â @KevinE03Â  No actually it's literally something you are born able too do or not. And you cannot ever change that. Its a litteral disability.  Called aphantasia.  I read constantly as a child, never realized people actually SAW what they were thinking until highschool art class. Teacher called it bullshitt until I got tested.   If you can't do it even a little you never will. Example, I have never seen a purple elephant in my life, I cannot create that image.  I can't see a new Christmas tree in my head I can't picture the tree then one by one add decorations, only memories of old ones as information. Rarely I'll have a general idea of the image but it's not something you can change.  I know my old family tree was white with blue decor.  But again, I can't picture that in some 3d space.  My dreams are almost always memories as well, never have I ever dreamed a place I haven't been.  Anyway, many people litteraly don't have a minds eye.

Â @FeedMeSaltÂ  Hi! If you are still interested in this, a quick search will lead you to this video, by Proko (with a host that has aphantasia) that gives insight and advice on how to go about drawing without being able to visualize in their heads ( link: https://youtu.be/LWgXSxxEjgs ). The reason they did not touch on this is probably because people who cannot visualize mentally are the outliers not the norm, so it probably wasn't on their radar at the time of recording. There are materials on Youtube that people with this affliction can use for free.
Â @pinnappel713Â  Ty so much!
Rip Kim jung gi

Â @KevinE03Â  pretty sure they were referring to aphantasia, in which case yes visualizing is something people can't do. Please don't just write people off when they say they can't visualize, it's not the same as someone saying "oh this person is so talented too bad I don't have the talent".  Some people really cant.That doesn't mean they cannot draw, but they definitely can't follow the same advice kim jung gi gives of having a mini you go around the scene.

Anyone who writes a how to draw like Kim Jung gi on a thumbnail or title is making clickbait. You might as well be writing how to fight like Mike Tyson. Sometimes the answer is, donâ€™t because you are not them. Trying to draw like someone who literally can visualize all of the construction stably within his imagination is dumb. Learn to draw like someone who shows their work. Learn to draw like someone who uses proper techniques to create structural basis for the detail. He is the Art equivalent of a teleporter, he just pops stuf into reality with no construction or even a hint that he has plans for anything he does.   Might as well do a course on how to draw like AI because youâ€™re going to get just as much evidence of process in the work. Meaning zero.

Â @sharkshimi5451Â yeah he obviously has a level of visualization skill that is completely unmatched, he is the pinnacle of genius when it comes to visualizing. Even people that can visualize often need to make some form of construction and gesture to keep it fresh in there memory and that visualization is typically not stable but like a dream tends to morph and change over time. Being able to hold a single image in your head is something Tibetan Monks dedicate their lives to learning it is not normal for anyone to just be able to see Imagination as clearly as life.

Â @sharkshimi5451Â  although I do wonder are you saying that some people have zero visual memory. That is a trip to imagine not being able to recall how anything looks at all. It sounds like a real handicap, is there memory solely narrative? Do they recognize people or so they have to talk to or get to know someone over again before they properly recognize someone from there past,   I have a bad memory for faces myself even though I am really good at visualization compared to most, but I do forget how people look after a few years of not seeing them if I am not shown pictures. It sounds really hard to think here are people who lose track of visual memory instantaneously.

Â @dorjedriftwood2731Â  We disagree. Learning how someone works from their own conversation is vitally important for adding hteir skills to your own. That's not clickbait. It's literally how learning art works.   We stand on the shoulders of the giants that came before us, adding their skills and knowledge to our own. He was a profoun talent but there are many out there applying his approach to their own work. Seeign someone do something amazing just means that it's possible.  Mike Tyson got beat at different stages of his career too. Beginning, prime and later. Respect the talented people who come before you but don't put them on a pedestal  and limit yourself by saying what they do will never be possible for you. We don't believe that for you and neither should you. Learn and grow!

Â @dorjedriftwood2731Â  I'm of the mind that Gi probably had some sort of savant syndrome. His ability to think in 3D at such a young age is genuinely insane and astonishing to me. Obviously a lot of his visual skill/library comes from the sheer amount he draws but I don't think it should be overlooked that he was able to understand 3D space from such a young age. He truly was a generational artist

Â @dorjedriftwood2731Â  Some people have zero ability to visualize whatsoever. It's quite interesting. I'm not really sure how it works either, but a common sort of way that people with aphantasia describe it is conceptualizing rather than visualizing. They know what a horse is, they know what it looks like they know what it does conceptually, but they're unable to visualize it. They know what makes it up, but they can't see it. I myself am not too familiar still with the exact definition of visualization and mind's eye, etc, but it is a really interesting phenomenon.

Â @sharkshimi5451Â  "i think he was a savant" followed by "obviously he drew a lot" like dude, he drew a lot. like, A LOT. and all the time he was drawing he was observing and pushing himself, experimenting and applying what he's learned. He's said he was drawing 12 hours a day in highschool, and when he was in college he would still spend most of his time drawing. This isnt a savant, this is a guy who absolutely loves drawing, spends most of their time drawing, and is constantly pushing himself to improve for thousands of hours a year for decades. obviously they'd get really good.
Nah. Generative AI trash can exist but it doesn't replace the good stuff that exists in the world. That still exists and is just as marvelous as it was before generative AI existed.
â€‹â€‹Â @ProkoTVÂ let us live long to see what will happen.

â€‹Â @jafarr11Â You can already look around and find other things that have been factory produced for examples. We don't have to wait.  Even though Wonderbread is on shelves, rustic handmade bread still exists and people pay a premium for it to exist that way. It's the bread you get when you want to impress somebody or that people learn to make themselves as a homemaking art.  Shooting photos or movies on film still exists in an age of digital cameras because people acknowledge is has character that they want when they have the means to pay for it.  And portrait art still exists even though cameras exist.   The hand of the creator is desired when the means exists to pay for it. It adds something that can't be algorithmically supplemented. AI will never really replace human creation. But people looking for a shortcut have always settled for something trashy. This is just another example of that.  Kin Jung Gi won't ever be "replaced" by a machine or even another person who does something similar to what he did. His voice was his own and that's what makes it special. A new artists will go and make something similar that will do it to the next level of proficiency, but that won't be AI. And they'll inject their own inspiration, story, and originality.

Nope! There's a set of skills and techniques he deploys and describes within our videos with him. How you use them and what knowledge you have built up may not be as fully developed as his was at the moment you see here, but he had to hone the skill too.   It's not like if you look at his childhood sketchbook, he drew exactly like he did as an adult.  Knowing how the artists you like work is a MASSIVE leg up in doing what they do or even surpassing them. It's up to you to apply that, though.

Â @ProkoTVÂ  Really? Where could I find that? It might make me feel a bit better about myself since basically everything I do is terrible and makes me feel bad and I can't even express it my art and everything else I do is so bad.

@ We have multiple videos with him on the channel. Over those videos, he shares different parts of his process, how he visualizes things and what he feels is important to how he works.  It's not any one moment in one video.  Try watching through them and take some notes about what he does that might be different from what you do.   Then, adapt those to your strengths and combine it with what you know how to do currently and identify what you may still need to learn or practice.
We think this was more of a product of his brain ROM, actually.  A wide visual library is a great mental resource for an artist.

The premise of this video is funny.  He clearly has no technique.  It's pure natural talent, observation and a massive amount of practice.  That's it.  People cannot learn his "technique" because it's all done organically.  No guide lines, no perspective vanishing points, no breaking down figures to building blocks or anything like that.  He literally sees what he wants to draw and inks his vision.  There is only one Kim Jung Gi.  He cannot pass on his style or technique.

How to draw like kim jung gi? Step one and only step: Be Kim Jung Gi. simple and not simple at the same time..  The thing is, you don't need to draw LIKE him, you just learn from him, personalize the perspective you've learned and practice till you're heart is satisfied with the art, meaning/value and story you are making. For yourself, and others to see.

KJG is an absolute legend and was incredible to witness at work! But every artist who comes before us paves they way to further the pursuit of great art through master studies.  While no one will be the exact same legendary human artist, someone who's even better will come along by being inspired by his and other artists' work. And that's a GOOD thing! He shared his knowledge freely to ensure that we artists have that chance!

Is the amount of details in his drawings that make his drawings just unreal. How he remembers even the tiniest details is crazy, and how he adds them to his drawings where it needs to be. This goes beyond drawing. And is not just like he draws one specific thing good, he knows how to draw everything. He's not set to one specific thing like some artist. This guy literally could have drawn everything in the world and add all the details it had.

The title of this video is hilarious. Might as well say, "How to fly like Superman" or "How to Ball like Kobe"! Actually those two are probably more possible than the premise that you could teach someone to draw like the man. I mean, come on.

He was so amazing at what he did and made it look so easy and effortless... true and pure talent always seems to do that. He just had such a unique way of seeing the world around him. His passing has definitely left a GIANT empty hole in the world of Art and originality. Especially in these trying times of generic AI generated nonsense that passes for "art", and that's saturating the internet. I truly miss and appreciate him now more than ever. Thank God that his art will live on, so we can always look back and enjoy it forever. Rest easy, Kim Jung Gi. ğŸ–¤âœŒï¸

If you've ever gone deep into drawing, doodling, sketching...or just art in general. You understand that this comes from hours and houts, days and weeks, many years of playing. Playing with your pencil on paper, a simple bic pen, or a favorite brand of marker. As a kid I never thought whether something I was drawing was good or not...I just drew. As time went on I became better and started buildinng an arsenal of techniques, shapes, scribbles, shortcuts, and patterns. I later learned what I was doing was a combination the Loomis method, contour drawing, and scribbling in guide lines. Playing...just drawing for the sake of drawing. Not taking it too serious or creating perfect art. From this I built my own style.   Art by. Poncho

I admire this guy so much and listen carefully to his advice, but I don't think he understood he had a unique ability to visualize things in his head like he did. That's not something you can really train. He obviously had some kind on hyperphantasia happening in his head. You can't train a hypophantasic or aphantasic brain into visualizing stuff. Its the way the brain is wired.

Yooooo a lot these look like pure continuous contour!?! Thats fucking nuts, oh man this whole vid is nourishing me rn. A good trick to help with recalling scenery is sitting in a scene you wanna draw say youre sitting st the park and the way everything is presented in front of you would make a good drawing.  Blink as much as you can like youre using a shudder camera to take pictures. After wards try to recall as many details as possible before looking again. Its also a neat technique to teach situational awareness. Just keep tryng to see how many details you get right befor having to look back. As aa drawing exercise its great because you sometimes add in details that werent there leading to a whole new scene

i almost cried when I heard he went pro at 27. I started drawing seriously at 14, but due to various factors, didn't improve much until recently. I'm currently 25 with a normal office job, grinding art every day after work for hours, wondering if I'm too old to be trying to break into this industry. I realize now I shouldn't be discouraged by the fact that I'm a "late bloomer" in art, it's never too late to learn. And as Kim said, once you have a good grasp of the fundamentals of perspective and drawing in 3D, improving becomes really fast. When I saw that he was coming to paris my hometown for the first time in 10 years I immediatly seized the opportunity to go watch his work at the gallery, but I got much more than that, I saw him drawing live in front of us, with an alien facilty, I even got the chance to get one of his very last signed sketchbook. I couldn't be more happy, I told all my friend "come ! Come to the gallery see his work, it might a once in a lifetime opportunity !" If only we knew, he was there standing in front of all of us full of joy sympathy and sharing drawing advices and good jokes, an less than 72 hours later he was gone, still unable to realize. But what I can say today is an gigantic thank you to this awesome master that gave us (and will) so much inspiration, and on a more personal note, surely one of the most precious objects in my artist life, a drawing in his book that I will keep forever. Thanks for everythink master.

so he has multiple processes going on his head that break down multiple things at once due to these so called "mini-mes" that help him organize his thoughts & solve things quicker instead of doing 1 thing at a time or having everything jumbled up, this was very interesting & informative, not sure if i could really bring out multiple thoughts & throw them into folders then solve them all at the same time then remember it all, this guy must've either been born with something or started very early when his brain was barely developed & built this system during that age because that's quite a monstrous skill to have, i don't think even with years of practice you'd get used to doing such a thing, it'd be like multi-tasking except relying on memory & thoughts while also working with precision & knowing what you're doing, i can hardly wrap my head around the thought of me breaking down multiple things relating to my work at once whilst also working with a clear enough mind to be able to focus  this guy's insane, much respect to the people that go to the extreme in what they love doing, very motivating & always interesting to see, thanks to everyone at proko for always sharing & helping the art community out, been watching this channel's videos years ago before i even started getting into art

you guys should have touched on the fact that MILLIONS of humans cannot visualize in their heads. its not something you can learn, you are born with it or you aren't.
Â @FeedMeSaltÂ  Visualizing is a skill not an ability. Go watch movies or read books(books work especially well).

Â @KevinE03Â  No actually it's literally something you are born able too do or not. And you cannot ever change that. Its a litteral disability.  Called aphantasia.  I read constantly as a child, never realized people actually SAW what they were thinking until highschool art class. Teacher called it bullshitt until I got tested.   If you can't do it even a little you never will. Example, I have never seen a purple elephant in my life, I cannot create that image.  I can't see a new Christmas tree in my head I can't picture the tree then one by one add decorations, only memories of old ones as information. Rarely I'll have a general idea of the image but it's not something you can change.  I know my old family tree was white with blue decor.  But again, I can't picture that in some 3d space.  My dreams are almost always memories as well, never have I ever dreamed a place I haven't been.  Anyway, many people litteraly don't have a minds eye.

Â @FeedMeSaltÂ  Hi! If you are still interested in this, a quick search will lead you to this video, by Proko (with a host that has aphantasia) that gives insight and advice on how to go about drawing without being able to visualize in their heads ( link: https://youtu.be/LWgXSxxEjgs ). The reason they did not touch on this is probably because people who cannot visualize mentally are the outliers not the norm, so it probably wasn't on their radar at the time of recording. There are materials on Youtube that people with this affliction can use for free.
Â @pinnappel713Â  Ty so much!
Rip Kim jung gi

Â @KevinE03Â  pretty sure they were referring to aphantasia, in which case yes visualizing is something people can't do. Please don't just write people off when they say they can't visualize, it's not the same as someone saying "oh this person is so talented too bad I don't have the talent".  Some people really cant.That doesn't mean they cannot draw, but they definitely can't follow the same advice kim jung gi gives of having a mini you go around the scene.

Anyone who writes a how to draw like Kim Jung gi on a thumbnail or title is making clickbait. You might as well be writing how to fight like Mike Tyson. Sometimes the answer is, donâ€™t because you are not them. Trying to draw like someone who literally can visualize all of the construction stably within his imagination is dumb. Learn to draw like someone who shows their work. Learn to draw like someone who uses proper techniques to create structural basis for the detail. He is the Art equivalent of a teleporter, he just pops stuf into reality with no construction or even a hint that he has plans for anything he does.   Might as well do a course on how to draw like AI because youâ€™re going to get just as much evidence of process in the work. Meaning zero.

Â @sharkshimi5451Â yeah he obviously has a level of visualization skill that is completely unmatched, he is the pinnacle of genius when it comes to visualizing. Even people that can visualize often need to make some form of construction and gesture to keep it fresh in there memory and that visualization is typically not stable but like a dream tends to morph and change over time. Being able to hold a single image in your head is something Tibetan Monks dedicate their lives to learning it is not normal for anyone to just be able to see Imagination as clearly as life.

Â @sharkshimi5451Â  although I do wonder are you saying that some people have zero visual memory. That is a trip to imagine not being able to recall how anything looks at all. It sounds like a real handicap, is there memory solely narrative? Do they recognize people or so they have to talk to or get to know someone over again before they properly recognize someone from there past,   I have a bad memory for faces myself even though I am really good at visualization compared to most, but I do forget how people look after a few years of not seeing them if I am not shown pictures. It sounds really hard to think here are people who lose track of visual memory instantaneously.

Â @dorjedriftwood2731Â  We disagree. Learning how someone works from their own conversation is vitally important for adding hteir skills to your own. That's not clickbait. It's literally how learning art works.   We stand on the shoulders of the giants that came before us, adding their skills and knowledge to our own. He was a profoun talent but there are many out there applying his approach to their own work. Seeign someone do something amazing just means that it's possible.  Mike Tyson got beat at different stages of his career too. Beginning, prime and later. Respect the talented people who come before you but don't put them on a pedestal  and limit yourself by saying what they do will never be possible for you. We don't believe that for you and neither should you. Learn and grow!

Â @dorjedriftwood2731Â  I'm of the mind that Gi probably had some sort of savant syndrome. His ability to think in 3D at such a young age is genuinely insane and astonishing to me. Obviously a lot of his visual skill/library comes from the sheer amount he draws but I don't think it should be overlooked that he was able to understand 3D space from such a young age. He truly was a generational artist

Â @dorjedriftwood2731Â  Some people have zero ability to visualize whatsoever. It's quite interesting. I'm not really sure how it works either, but a common sort of way that people with aphantasia describe it is conceptualizing rather than visualizing. They know what a horse is, they know what it looks like they know what it does conceptually, but they're unable to visualize it. They know what makes it up, but they can't see it. I myself am not too familiar still with the exact definition of visualization and mind's eye, etc, but it is a really interesting phenomenon.

Â @sharkshimi5451Â  "i think he was a savant" followed by "obviously he drew a lot" like dude, he drew a lot. like, A LOT. and all the time he was drawing he was observing and pushing himself, experimenting and applying what he's learned. He's said he was drawing 12 hours a day in highschool, and when he was in college he would still spend most of his time drawing. This isnt a savant, this is a guy who absolutely loves drawing, spends most of their time drawing, and is constantly pushing himself to improve for thousands of hours a year for decades. obviously they'd get really good.

Â @salty_3k506Â  I feel like there's a difference between hyperphantasia and like, understanding how to draw.   Hyperphantasia is the ability to create very vivid mental images, I for example can only create faint images, it mostly looks black  I could be wrong but im pretty sure the hyperphantasia im talking about has deeper links with the brain's structure and not just something you can learn.  If I want to draw a car, I have to look at a car irl or an image of one, or at least understand what pieces are placed next to which, or sketch structures beneath it.  the way he describe's the "mini-me's". concept sounds like he has a distinct ability to create scenes in his head, that he can explore, which sounds like something akin to hyperphantasia.  but yeah, regardless, the practice is really what ties it together

Â @rlzerocyÂ  Yeah, but this ability to memorize, visualize and think in 3D space is something that can be learned.   Every time I look at reference for a car, I remember its structure better afterwards. So naturally, the better I understand the car's struture and look at references, the better and more accurately I can draw it.   I'm sure that you could imagine your room and "move around" in it in your head because you have seen it a thousand times. But not with other objects because you don't know them as well.    Also, you don't need to visualize things perfectly in order to draw well. Almost no one can visualize things "well", mostly it's just a mash of ideas that has no concrete visualization. And here's a video on aphantasia: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LWgXSxxEjgs

Â @salty_3k506Â  yeah, definitely the 3d structure thing. The more you do it or the more rules/guideline you're aware of (perspective, volume, contours, etc. idk) you kinda get a feel for where the next lines or shapes, have to be, or at least know if something about the structure feels off, and why.  The way he describes the mini me's thing is just fascinating to me, I suppose If you've seen a certain place or thing before a multitude of times, youd have enough memories to simulate movement around it.  doing it with made up hypothetical objects sounds amazing and bizzare.   But I guess as you said, you can kinda mish mash things you have in your visual vocabulary and I guess make new hybrid objects or landscapes or something from those images and the base shapes that make them up.   anyway you know what, bottomline is, that's some cool ass shit.

When I was around 6 years old, I had a friend, who was my best friend at the time, named Marlon.   Him and I were best friends because we both loved drawing. His style was more on the anime style, and my forte was this sort of 'realistic' type. Family members would come over and my parents would brag how great I could draw someone pretty well for such a small age. And so people would naturally sit for me and I'd draw them. Afterwards, they would remark how precocious my abilities were. Looking back, I don't know if they were being nice to a kid or not because I barely remember my drawing ability at the time to accurately judge it now.  But I do recall this one exercise Marlon and I would both do. This little game, if you will.   We'd both challenge each other to look at an image or character for a few minutes, and then put the image away, and try to draw from memory that image as accurately as possible. And whoever got it the most would win for that particular character or image. We'd do it over and over. During classes, during lunches etc. Then We'd even watch cartoons at home and come to school and challenged each other to draw some of the characters we saw in a new episode, from memory.   Needless to say, we were pretty known throughout school as the two best artists in our school.   I never developed my drawing abilities beyond the age of 8 or 9. Lots of things happened around those times. I moved houses, and consequently, schools every 2 years because of either eviction, or parents getting new work.   I picked up different habits and hobbies. I could dance, or mimic entire scenes of cartoons so i could recite and perform them back at school to my new friends. Especially around the beginning of the South Park days, etc that led to theatre and other stuff.   I still wonder about my friend Marlon today. And in the last 3 years, I've been slowly getting back into drawing, and I can't help but imagine what it would have been like had I fostered that drawing ability until today. I would have been able to have the same or similar skill to draw anything from memory.   There's still hope, but there are so many other variables involved now as 30 year old man. But boy do I always wonder.

I think that drawing like kim jong un is not about perspective or anatomy and all those things. I mean, there are perspective without grids and anatomy and knowledge of the objects he puts in the drawing, but most people with mid-tier skill can do those things. The key element imo is really thinking about the lines you put on paper. When you draw, think about how you could do the same line differently. Think like, one minute for every line. Practice this way. Then, shorten the time more and more, and do it over and over, until you get the best line possible in like 70% of the instances.

Takeways.. obviously Kim Jung Gi is enormously talented, but follow these rules and you will undoubtedly improve as an artist. 1. Always be drawing 2. Draw as many different things as possible 3. Draw those things in as many different perspectives as possible; visualize every object in 3d. 4. Have the rage of a drunken Korean when drawing 5. Theory and fundamentals are important; refer to #1 until theory and fundamentals are second nature. 6. Fear of making mistakes prevents progress.  7. The medium doesn't matter; use what you like, refer to #1

Step 1 should've been; You need a photographic memory. Everyone who doesn't have such a incredible memorization should just forget about trying to draw like Kim Jung Gi. I forgive you because of your username but Gosh did you missed the point. He doesn't have a photographic memory, he has the ability to visualize different perspective of the same scene. Â @_Nyxus_Â  , I don't think it is mental illness but instead an indoctrination of the educational  grading system that all of us are subjected to . The grading system  forces us to see things that are relative to us being an  A , B , C , D , or F  as to how we measure up . The grading system that are instill in us from childhood makes us instinctively compare ourselves to others . When schools haves art contest and there are career art critics  these things only reinforces  the behavior to criticize or praise each others  work . It's the judgment of art work that pushes a person to progress their skills but the negative effect is that it can also discourage a person as well .  It would be nice that everyone can be considered an accomplished artist based on effort , but then it wouldn't be very interesting to read comic books or visit art museums where as  the art is of stick figures .

Â @mannybruce8950Â  I do mostly agree with that, but my brain legit makes it hard to do anything most days, let alone fight my critical demons. Depression is a horrid thing and a real thing, so is ADHD. The inability to focus makes it very difficult to learn and comprehend. Aphantasia, even though there are artists with it, also makes it difficult to understand how others "see." There's a LOT that can contribute to many ways someone thinks. But that doesn't invalidate someone's struggles and mental illness and how it affects their artistic growth.  But I'm serious when I say I agree with your statement as well. The grading system sucks so bad, especially when the higher grades students get praised constantly while those struggling get yelled at or they're not shown proper care. Imagine if we were all free to learn without the worry for being better than others or "don't be like that one kid making bad grades" kinda comments. I think we'd thrive a hell of a lot more.

This is very true. I also realize this comment is old asf, but I just wanted to add that while I agree with your sentiment, I don't think most people will ever draw like kim jung gi. You should certainly strive to be the best you can be, of course, and I do the same. But the sheer ability to draw anything, especially mechanical things without a reference, just off of the top of his head takes a special kind of brain â€“ even if he says he doesn't have photographic memory. You can certainly learn how to draw as good as him, but that kind of off hand knowledge of images and how things look? I really don't think that can be taught. He is simply built different.   Now, I'm not saying that he shouldn't inspire you, or that you can't aspire to be like him, but the way he thinks is different than most people.

Honestly I'd advise people to decide on why they want to make their art rather than keep practicing and you'll be at Kim Jung Gi's level one day, because that's just not true. Even discipline itself is a sort of talent that not everyone has. And there's definitely not many people who could do so much details even after years of practice. And I personally think that for me to reach this level, it'll take my whole life and dedication. I like art, yes, but I don't like just the drawing aspect, there are other things I want to use art for. So no, I can't be him, slight mope, but whatever, I'll focus on other aspects. Yeah, well, in reality, you all probably draw dog turds in comparison to him. That's just objective fact, people. There are levels in everything we do, and no matter how hard you try or practice, or don't complain and whine, as you so put it... some just don't have the ability to reach that level. And while this fellow is an artist... it takes a bit of imagination stretching to label comic doodlers as legitimate "aritsts"... the word is lobbed around too liberally, like Genius. People play guitar for 15 years, only to see a 12 year old who has been playing for a year, shredding better than they ever hoped. People who play baseball from preschool up to college, yet never make even the minors. Takes more than practice to be great at something. And no matter what your medium may be, you just have to accept the fact that there will always be those out there that make you look like a noob who should find another passion.

The common consensus here is that hardwork + time = mastery. Which is just false. You wouldnt say the same thing for music would you? If every musician just put hours of practicing instead of anything else, they would all be the most successful and the masters of their music/art? We know for a fact that this isnt the case, because I know musicians who have spent decades making the worst, and unpopular music and never improve. Please dont treat art like its a manual labour training, its not like the gym. Its literally an art, its in the name. Some musicians have far less hours on their "belt" than some crazy-asses singing their life out on the streets with an out of tune voice - and become instantly recognised because of their true and original talent. All of the 'art's are beyond just putting in the training and the work, but of course it is obviously essential for any talent.

Â @blackbird8837Â  Well yes ... and no. When you take drawing classes you will see a lot of different approaches by different people. Some draw the outlines and then fill in the details. Other people start from the inside and work to the outside. But eventually if you draw/paint really a lot? It becomes like a second nature to you. As I have learned over the years the trick is to not work around your mistakes, so to speak, but to make it a part of your art. It is an illustration not a potrait or like a picture where it has to be as precise and close to the real thing as possible. Gi is impressive. But the method can be adobted by pretty much anyone. Just as how everyone can learn to play (good) soccer. But of course not everyone will be a world class champion. But you can still learn it and be decent with it. When I used to draw like every day, at some point certain positions, figures, etc. become like a second nature to you. Muscle memory if you so will. Of course not everyone can be exactly like Gi. But I would say a lot of people, if they are dedicated, can get somewhat close to the efficiency and quality. Takes only 15+ years of experience I assume XD.

Â @CrniWukÂ  No. He literally says that he uses parts of the drawing itself as guidelines, as @Georgia Rose already pointed out and on which I elaborated.  But yes, working your muscle memory will lead to accessing those skills more easily and with better outcome.

Â @sarroumarbeu6810Â  Kim Jung Gi said in an interview he doesn't need references because he'd already used so many references in his younger years persistently that he didn't need that anymore.   What I understand to be the inference behind this is that he'd subconsciously studied the rules behind the reality he was about to lay with his pen on paper and you don't need perfect memory to capture a scene nearly perfectly if you've seen very similar scenes (or small elements of this scene) previously quite frequently.   I think this is the power of delegating the strenuous task of computing an enormous amount of information to the subconscious by making it a habit. When you do something routinely with an expected reward/punishment, your brain adapts to it very quickly making it a habit.  For example, you get a dog from a shelter today and want to train it to recognize a bell ring as lunch time so for a couple of days, whenever you ring a bell, you give the dog lunch. Eventually, it reaches the point where the dog practically salivate when you only ring the bell (eventually it salivates when it's lunch time). In the same way, you could program your own brain to skip the difficult and time consuming task of intensely observing each element of an observed source eventually, whenever you draw, your subconscious takes up the brunt of the work, remembering the important details...blah blah blah I'm getting tired typing this damned YouTube comment at 2am im going to sleep now sorry for any grammatical errors but not rly sorry ;)

You can't learn to draw like this guy simply because you are not a savant and your brain is not unlocked for you in your subconscious. Some people are born with (or will they acquire from brain damage in a later age) access to the subconscious part of the brain which is meant to be for real-time processing of reality, billions of countings in a matter of a second. Therefore they are able to use this part of subconscious processing power to draw, imagine, see the world in fractals, do great math, etc, to observe something in their mind which should be originally hidden from them. To learn consciously to draw like this would take you maybe 1000 years and you would need to memorize zillions of patterns from all angles and your drawing would be still memorized drawing. He paints and draws from his subconscious mind, he can't really explain why is that happening for him and you can't ever learn it. Only if you maybe had brain damage and your brain would make you access that part of the subconscious. It is not a talent and has nothing to do with talent. This guy only shows how miraculous our brain is and what it does for us in the background of our conscious mind so we can walk, speak, see things, keep balance, and millions of other things without a conscious understanding of how that happens for us. The same thing with his drawing. We can only observe it as a miracle of a lucky man.

yep, you get it.  the thing people tend to miss with KJG is focusing on the nuts and bolts of "how to draw".  it's mostly not about how to draw...it's about the skill underneath drawing, and that's how to see - with and without your eyes.  this type of drawing is a (imo) spiritual practice of strengthening your focus, attention, and visual imagination, and you don't get there without a true love and interest in observing and visualizing everything you can imagine.  the funny thing is, "daydreaming" like this is a skill we all possess to perfection as kids, but we lose it as we grow up.  when he's talking about "floating the image in your mind", that's the type of stuff that requires daily practice.  at first, it's hard to even hold a simple, un-detailed object in your mind's eye, without it popping in and out of existence - it's less of an image, and more of a concept.  but as you train to "see" more and more, you can go from that fuzzy conceptual image to "walking around" a head or car in your mind, to placing yourself inside a cohesive, detailed scene, and observing it in all its detail.  this is the work that's going to get you where KJG is.  the drawing itself is a means to an end, but the true meat of the practice is strengthening that ability to imagine and understand form.  if you're drawing without really focusing on the form and substance of what you're drawing, it's not gonna help you.  thankfully, it's something you can practice all day, everyday, in any kind of situation, whether you have a pencil in your hand or not.

Depends on the type of artist, but most will use references on occasion. But there are differences between how professionals tend to use references. Beginners draw references based on what they're looking at directly. Professionals look at the reference and manipulate everything they want to about it to get what they want. A beginner sees a reference of a dragon and draws exactly what they see. A professional sees that picture and then draws the dragon from a completely different angle only using the basics of dragon anatomy to complete their drawing (if that's what they're going for). Which is quite impressive and scary to even approach imo. I certainly couldn't do that with confidence and I've been drawing for at least 2 hours a day since I was 15 years old. I'm turning 21 in a few months.

"Don't draw what you see, draw what you have seen" Is what my life drawing teacher once told me. Drawing someone on paper, no matter how realistic it maybe, is all fake in the end of the day. So  mix drawing with what you already know (like anatomy or structural elements) and what you see to get a better drawing.

Perspective always was what makers or brakes a drawing for me. It doesn`t matter the artstyle, if you nail the perspective, in my opinion. (and proportion as well, even in caricatures some artists doesn`t get quite right)

god of draw

â€‹@Any Rebel I mean, it depends on who you're talking to and what your objectives are as an artist. Teachers are there to help you learn the skill of observation, which will help you as an artist no matter your style.   The process of copying images by drawing them solidifies those images in your mind, and the more you draw those images and new images, the more your drawing will change. If you don't draw new things, then you're stuck drawing the same old things.   What you consume by drawing is forwarded to your creative side when you start producing. For example, by pushing myself to draw different trees I now have a larger visual library to reference when I want to create a new drawing. So, it's like visual muscle memory -- you just gotta DO it.
real life savant
Observing an object then drawing it from angles other than the one I viewed it is the most obviously powerful exercise that I wasn't doing.

want me to draw you a cabinet i can.. want me to draw you a human i cant.. want me to make you a 3d cabinet i can.. want me to make you a 3d character that you draw.. well if its a toon character type like bender or lord nibbler, i can  pull it off.. if its a realistic human.. i fail. i hated art classes.. teachers were so lazy they would literally just say draw.. im like ok.. that doesn't help me in my weaknesses.. so i do finish carpentry.. but im getting old i wish i was doing 3d work and making money to quit carpentry.. also when i was in art it seemed most already had what it would take to make it drawing at very young.. so it always made me not to want to even draw around them. they naturally could draw humans so easily.. and so backgrounds were easy too. for them.. but i was always more technical.. it actually make me mad i cant draw human and make 3d realistic humans.. easier.. i even stop in 3d because of it.. and even i mainly did it to make a few weapon mods for games.. and i suck at texturing also.. so in my 3d also it showed i can make stuff look too perfect and not realistic with flaws ect.. same with my texture style. so i kinda gave up on that too lol. one character i make in 3d you can see.. on blendswap.com.. marvin the martian.. lol.. my comp with all my 3d stuff also died a long time ago and i lost a lot of work on it so that was depressing also. lost lots of good models.. and even some decent characters and animation rigs that took forever to make ect.. bleh. i also hate having my  art on comps because of that reason.. anyways good channel.. cya

Kim Jung Gi: Yes

The thin one he uses in the video is the 'pentel brush sign pen artist' and the one he commonly uses in his big drawings is the 'pentel color brush pen' (obviously) in the color black. These pens are imo very nice and comfortable to draw with after some practice and give beautiful rough lines and strokes. I hope this helps for anyone that wants to draw with a brush :)

Â @Zaire82Â  that's true, but also a tool you use actually matter.

Â @TheKirov21Â  I know I don't deny that, but a decent artist shouldn't be limited by materials. I've drawn some pretty nice stuff using a blue papermate pen and a lined paper notebook, which I took a photo of and used a black and white filter on. Looks like some beautiful linework despite the limitations. If it weren't on lined paper, some of them would be among my best drawings.  Papermate handwriting pens are actually pretty good as far as stationary goes. They don't get smudged by erasers and have smooth lines. I'd recommend them if you want to do linework on a non-existent budget.

The God of Ink

This guy is seriously inspiring. And the end of the video really hits home. I often find myself judging myself for not having accomplished more. Time and Time again I have to tell myself that it's the beginning, I'm 21, I have all the time in the world in front of me. I'm happy I stumbled on this right now, at the end of 2019. Because 2020 is when I'm wanting to really light a fire under my ass and start having completed works to show off to people.   For me it would be a dream come true to somehow make a living off of art. But I know the likelihood of that happening is small, even if I become skilled. So for me my goal is just to get the stories that have been gestating in my brain out to people, because otherwise they will die with me. And that feels like a disservice to the characters I have breathed life into.

One critique is I'm not so sure that when he says "I make mini me's and put them into the scene" he is being metaphorical. He later references visualising objects in your mind and rotating it on any orientation. Unless he's said otherwise, I think he actually means that he is imagining the entire scene from other perspectives. I'm nowhere near his level, but I do visualise objects in a similar way - working with steel you often have dozens of parts that come together, starting out as flat cutouts, that them very bent, and then welded or bolted together, and I visualise the entire exploded diagram in my head.  I only wish I were as good at figure drawing, so I guess I should just start drawing more.

Animation is a completely different kind of art. An animator's mind should be a able to comprehend perspective and summarise the details of what they're making into a few dozen lines, easily. They can't spend an hour on every frame, that'd take months, and you'd only get an animation a little over a minute long.

Â BronzeGodÂ  Animators don't need to understand the same principles as drawers do.   Their objective is to churn out as many frames per second while still making them look fluid and attractive. If there's motion, you have to blend the frames together to make it smooth, which can result in some janky looking drawings. (Naruto Shippuden is famous for janky smears) Normal drawing needs you to understand exactly what you're wanting to draw and how to best convey it in a single motionless picture. If there's motion, you'd have to imply it through composition and perspective, etc. Doing that in the same way for an animation would ruin that animation.  Motion is the most obvious difference, but not the only one. Smears are highly unintuitive for normal artists, and are the hardest part of making a good animation. They're an art form in themselves, because of how weird they are.   I get the impression you have no personal experience on this matter, and are talking solely from observation. I am saying that's how it seems, by the way. Whether it's true or not doesn't matter.
Â BronzeGodÂ  Thanks for being civil, I thought my words might have come off as a bit insulting.
Â BronzeGodÂ  The only experience I have is failing to succeed in animating, repeatedly. I know the differences because of those failures.

Visualising is cool when you're good enough to translate it into paper, but when you're a beginner or even a total newbie, that will only get you fixed on your idea that you won't be able to draw. That was my issue for many years and I was getting frustrated easily. Instead I learnt to limit visualisation as much as possible so my drawing grows on the paper. This way I can easily adapt to what happens on my canvas. And only after that I was able to actually draw, enjoy it and improve. And the more I improve the more I allow myself to plan ahead before doodling first sketches.

What he says at 15:12 is KEY for anyone wanting to draw or paint more loosely and fluidly. He basically says that he used to draw very tightly and meticulously. Repetition of this technique is what led to an intuitive understanding of form until he no longer needed to have an iron grip on what he was drawing. The understanding was inside him so he could draw the lines as quickly and fluidly as he felt like and it would still turn out looking correct. If you feel like you draw too â€œtightâ€ just keep practicing over and over and really try to internalize the form, without thinking too much about the tightness or looseness. Before you can draw loosely you draw tightly, even a savant like Kim Jung Gi.

Â @omdano6432Â  youre dead wrong.  Style is a huge way to determine the skill level of an artist even if you dont like it. A simplified style can tell you that an artist is just as skilled as one who does highly detailed anatomical drawings.   How? Well style doesnt pop out of nowhere for the artist. Style comes with tons of studying other pros and simplifying what you see. Although an ordinary person might think that a cartoon/chibi artist is worse than an industry-level illustrator just because the style is "simpler". for example, the arms might not have as much detail, but truth is that a lot of that is concious decision making from the chibi artist.  So yes, you can tell a persons skill level by just their style. There ARE good and bad art styles and a lot of it comes down to how the artist simplifies the forms from real life and how well the features on the drawing work together to make a coherent style for the viewer to experience.

"You can not force fame or success" I really needed to hear this. I've wanted to get good enough to illustrate the stories I'm writing, but I've started drawing and writing later in life(now 25). Maybe I won't reach some levels of artistic ability in the next 5 years, but that doesn't mean I can't keep trying for the next 5 years after that. So, it really means that my motivation shouldn't be to do X thing before a certain age, but rather to maybe do X thing at any point while enjoying the ride.

the really motivating thing for me here is that he doesn't seem to use any crazy or complicated methods. It's simply :  observation of an object in real life or reference ->  use your memory/imagination to look at the object from different angles ->  look for the angle you find most interesting ->  draw a box that fits into that perspective ->  draw the object using the box as a helping grid ->  repeat over and over with different objects to make your inner library/memory/imagination grow

Visualizing a scene in your mind with every detail in it in a certain perspective (let alone in a fish-eye perspective) is more about how your brain works than it is about practicing. Some people have a gift for math, others for visualizing images. Sure, you can practice it until you're blue in the face and you might get better than the majority, but reaching Kim Jung Gi's level is next to impossible for mere mortals like us. When he explains how he draws the fish-eye images, he says he draws what he sees on the left, then in the middle, then on the right, but that would not give you a fish-eye perspective. When a 'normal' person would draw it, the scene would be all horizontal, not curved as looking through a fish-eye lens. There's something in his brain that automatically converts the lines, shapes and perspective into fish-eye, if that's what he wants to draw. For me, watching this video, is as depressing as it is mind blowing because I'm awe-struck but at the same time know that I will never reach his brilliance. Heck, I'd be happy if I could just find my own personal style and not try to measure myself with geniuses like Kim Jung Gi, he's just amazing.

Lot of people being discouraged in the comments but honestly y'all, y'all don't have to be Gi levels of good to be an amazing artist. It's a process and we all got our way of approaching things with different artistic philosophy, with a different journey too. Gi is an amazing creator and it's not impossible to get to where he is if you follow a similar ways of visualizing and internalizing the world, and particular ways of approaching your work, but y'all should be focused on improving and having fun with that process, and carving out your identity and do what you feel, feels best, and figuring out how you'd do these things instead of striving to become Kim Jung Gi 2. You can always learn from Kim Jung Gi but there's never any fun in tryna become Kim, because that's a very high standard to establish for yourself, especially if you're a newbie.

What I or anyone says shouldn't stop you if you actually care about it. If you're doing something just to become famous, rich, or popular on instagram you will always be discouraged and afraid because you're relying on the opinions of others for your self-worth. Reading the comments on this video, I have a feeling a lot of people here watching don't actually like making art because they're quickly discouraged by the mere existence of someone like Kim Jung Gi. Even if they have talent, they will never reach the top because they're just doing it for validation. Not a real love for art.

â€‹Â @filipvadas7602Â  Unless your goal is to do exactly what KJG does, I don't understand why someone would be intimidated by him. He makes a very specific type of work in (mostly) one medium. People commission him for his design aesthetic, but in no way can his type of art meet the demands for all commercial applications.  Again: if you're doing something out of love, opinions or the existence of highly talented people shouldn't stop you. I forgot where I read it, but the question basically was "if you were the last person on earth, would you still make art?" if the answer is no or you're unsure, then you're not actually in love with it. You're just in love with the idea of being an artist. I feel this is a major problem nowadays because of instagram, patreon, youtube, etc. People just want to make quick money (all that "side hustle" bullshit) and become internet famous. They see art as a tool to get them there, not as a part of who they are as a person.

Â @popesuavecitoxii2379Â  thing is that I  want to improve because I have a story in mind and I've been developing it for a few years now and I feel like a comic or graphic novel is the best way to tell it.  I LOVE how much detail you can put into a drawing, how a character's personality can be shown in their design, how much freedom it provides for creative visuals  But, seeing how quickly some people improve and how much more talent they have in comparison is discouraging cause art is a visual medium, and I'm simply worried I won't communicate the story as efectively as I would want

Â @nine-vi7rwÂ  I mean according to you and Filip's logic, if you aren't "born talented" then you should just give up. I was exaggerating obviously, but I never said that some artists do or don't have better aptitudes for the craft than others. My point is that the search and development of skill doesn't require some mystical gift or talent, and I grow irritated with people who say that without talent comparable to "geniuses" Then there's no point of doing anything. People treat this like some people are spiritually born inferior when it comes to the arts when that isn't the case like... at all.   "Oh you will never become one of the greats without prestigious talent birthed as you came!" "Oh the madness! Is there any point to you honing your craft if you don't have a god given aptitude for it? " "You will never be as good as the almighty Kim Jung Gi. Tis' time to give up, dear boy." "You are inferior. A mess, a joke. A nothing, without god given talent. Your natural given talent is where your craft is born. Your skills are only accessories."   I'm sick of it.     This idea that there'd be no such thing as "greatness" if people with particular aptitudes didn't exist is absurd, because it reinforces this idea that natural gifted talent supersedes all forms of skill no matter the dedication which is nonsense, and that searching for knowledge to improve is worthless if you don't have a special aptitude. You and other people in this thread cite specific and well-named individuals but fail to see others who are also very well-known for their craft that... probably weren't born "geniuses" as much as they developed into one... because they honed their craft and dedicated their entire lives to it. I never once even implied that people are always going to be born on the same exact footing considering there being a multitude of factors at play, because yeah, maybe there is a 7 year old boy who can recreate the Mona Lisa with cheap crayola paint, with their eyes closed, while playing Chopin with their other hand, however your dedication to the craft your passionate about plays in tandem with whatever your aptitudes are, and some people have different strengths within their craft, as well as outside it. Do you think Glenn Vilppu, Steve Huston, Stan Prokopenko, all your fav comic book artists,  animators, etc, were all just born naturally gifted for their craft? I guarantee you that isn't the case, and "talent" as I've made clear, isn't an immediate indicator of someone becoming "great" or "a genius". A person with no initial "talent" can develop their own way and become "geniuses" independent of whatever you deem "talent". That's the point I'm trying to make here, but everyone is seemingly making this out to be the upmost important variable when it comes to becoming "one of the greats" and I'm sorry, but there's just too many instances where that isn't the case for me to take that philosophy seriously. This whole "Oh nobody respects hard work, they only care about talent" crap is absolute bonkers to me.

I really hope this video destroys a lot of misconeptions people have about improving at art. KJG had a talent for perspective but that's not what made him great. He drew all the time and drew from life. He studied and practiced constantly and used his free social time to draw instead. He had the disadvantage of not having the best resources growing up but he still learned from trial and error. The most important thing he had was an interest and drive to improve and make art. If you don't want to spend all your time drawing and observing and making art your lifestyle, it's probably not for you. Don't worry if you don't feel talented or if that you aren't ever going to become a pro. Every pro I've heard talk about their education has said the same thing - practice.

"Don't draw what you see...Draw what you have seen."   This sounds deep and profound, and like something out of "The Matrix," but it's actually kind of silly, because anything you're seeing now, will become, a nanosecond later, what you HAVE seen, so they're basically the same thing. Memory is faulty to begin with, and, of course, with the passage of time, it becomes more fallible. This is a problem (maybe not for Kim Jung Gi) when using only your memory as a guide, because when you're relying only on your memory to draw, you're recreating what you THINK you saw, what you THINK an object looks like, how you THINK light reflects off of that object, etc., and quite often, what you think is not accurate.

Donâ€™t sketch just commit to one whole drawing and then see how you feel after a few hours, not just 5 min

Â @filipvadas7602Â  Then draw 100 horizontal lines + 100 vertical lines + 100 diagonal lines + 100 curvy lines + 100 wavy(same) lines each day in a week.   Then draw 100 circle + 100 square + 100 triangle + 100 hexagon, each day for a week.  Then draw 100 tube + 100 box + 100 pyramid, each day for a week.   Then try copy(not trace) 1 simple image (flower, cup, spoon, simpson, etc.) and repeat it for 10 times, different image for each day for a week.   And don't forget use pen(any) instead of pencil, and without any tool(raw hand).   It's just 28 days, so try to not stop even just 1 day.   This is said for build muscle memory to make your hand used to make a shape.  If after this training you still fail drawing something better, then you right.   Well this is just like little advice, so it's okay if you don't want to.

5:40 intuitive understanding over mathematical measurement = freeer feeling   8:30 reference every stroke to be a guideline fir perspective instead of needing a perfect mathematically correct vanishing point lines  Always think when you draw something, where is the upper &lower VP?  Where is the left and right VP? And from there try to FIRST draw the parts in the subject that can indicate those VP For Kim frog helmet he started with the front side if helmet which indicated right VP then the right side of helmet slightly indicated left side VP The toad eyes on helmet (when thinking about the square than hold sit inside) will tell where the upper VP is  Then the glasses give a reinforcement of where the right and left VP are   6:35 also can use contour lines to indicate form but also help reinforce VP for yourself throughout the drawing   9:30 once you are always thinking about objects as where they are in perspective/ â€œmastering the cubeâ€ Then you will improve very fast

5:33 I have a question for you Stan, I think I have heard you mentioning "the math behind perspective", but I saw Marshall's videos, I've read enough of perspective books to understand the basic concepts like vanishing points, horizon line, etc. but I've never seen math used beyond the basic concepts of perpendicular, parallel, oblique and at most angle measurements. Is that all there is? or is there a point where you really get deep into trigonometry?  In computer graphics you have a view matrix, a projection matrix and a model matrix that map 3d coordinates to 2d coordinates in the projection plane, I understand enough of it to look deeper and find how it could be done on paper, there's a lot of sine and cosine calculations, angles to radians, vectors, matrices and even quaternions, which I get, but I still feel like I am missing the glue between human drawing and computer drawing, and "the math behind perspective drawing" just seems to be it, yet I am not able to find math past elementary school math in perspective drawing, just a lot of intuition. Thank you and best regards!

If you were to ask a crowd of 100 to vote on an issue, would you be terribly surprised if 10 people voted against the motion, despite how original, acceptable, and commendable the proposal is? People are wonderfully diverse - there can never be a universally appealing video. There'll always be a few people who'll dislike a product that's enjoyed by millions. Also, the Internet provides us a wonderful kind of anonymity - the crowd camouflage. Hidden behind an innocuous screen-name, people on the Internet have absolutely no accountability, especially on video sharing platforms like YouTube. A lot of people dislike wonderful content out of spite as it can't be traced back to their actual selves, and sometimes just because they can. You will consistently find people being racist, homophobic, sexist, elitist, or just assholes to everyone else on the comment thread simply because they can. Many of them dislike a video simply because they can. It's a lot more about a viewer's inherent individuality than the contents of the video.

I don't know if this applies to you, but there are actually people who cant visualise in their minds eye. It is possible to overcome till a certain extent however, but it takes a lot of practice. To me its a very odd concept some people are acctualy unable to see stuff in their minds. There are videos about it on YouTube, hence me being introduced to the idea not everyone sees stuff in the same degree intheir head.

I can say I've always thought in words, meaning when I try to visualize images they are blurred and lack detail. Like a Hollywood depiction of a dream. I have been drawing for 15 years and what I found made the most profound difference was focusing on foundations. If I understand the logic behind perspective, value, etc then I don't have to rely on a powerful "mind's eye". I can simply build a visual library through practice and apply the rules that I know when drawing. It takes a little longer than I would like to create something I'm happy with, but for me it's a powerful reminder to slow down and learn to enjoy the act of doing something.
Draw stuff (anything and everything) from real life and your mind will gain the skill in time.

Â @filipvadas7602Â  Â well what everyone was trying to say is that if someone wants to become good they only have to keep working at it. Talent decides someone's path of growth, but it is not an indicator of success. If talent was the reason that an artist is good or not good, then we would find art throughout history that matches the level of photo quality that some artists are able to achieve today. The thing is though, that you can see a chronological improvement over time as artists studied form, value, space, etc and shared their findings with other artists. The art of the past pales in comparison to what people can do today with traditional mediums.   Another way you can think about my point is like this - someone may be born with an aptitude for math. This will naturally help them be a better engineer, but just because they are born that way does not mean they can immediately build a car.   Chalking up good art to talent is pretty offensive because no matter who the person is when you see them in the present, they were worse in the past than they are today. I would challenge you to try and think about talent not as the ceiling, but the floor, rather.

Â @mat43899Â  Constant study every day, it's not enough to be just drawing, it has to be for a specific purpose. Maybe it's perspective, one day, or maybe it's anatomy the second, I pick the fundamentals I seem to struggle with most and target them specifically. I have never gone to an art school or anything thing like that, nor have I paid a dime for any art courses online, everything I've gotten I've gotten for free; a lot of good resources on youtube. I did buy a few good books but that was all. Make sure to analyze artists and be real with yourself, study them and try and learn, and most importantly realize what they are doing that you are not, and then targetting that weak spot over and over and over until you feel it's less of a problem than something else. That's all it is, but I put in about 8--10 hours a day, and sleep like 5 or 6 hours a night, I gave up video games entirely. It's all day on the weekends pretty much. You have to sacrifice things for that precious time, it does not come easy I've gotten so frustrated I've literally torn up sketchbook pages. All this and it's only been one year!
